About Us Our Team Leadership Careers Job Openings Expertise Municipal Aviation Funding Featured Projects Funding Blog Contact Us About Us Our Team Leadership Careers Job Openings Expertise Municipal Aviation Funding Featured Projects Funding Blog Contact Us Search Search Home » Public Projects » Lake Lillian, MN Lake Lillian Infrastructure Improvement Project Project Updates 7/23/25 The project is wrapping up! Final seeding is taking place, and miscellaneous cleanup work will continue as needed. Thank you for your patience throughout construction. 5/6/25 All underground work has been completed. The Contractors are working on concrete curb and gutter, driveways and sidewalk.  Paving is being scheduled for late May or early June. Seeding and cleanup will be finished this summer. 11/15/24 Underground utility work will continue as long as weather permits. Paving will also continue as long as the hot-mix plants are open. Concrete work will occur depending on the weather. 11/5/24 The contractor work continues with the underground utilities on Park and 2 nd Street West, including pouring curb and gutter and paving all gravel surfaces with the 1 st lift of pavement on streets that were scheduled to be paved. Clean-up of the yards and seeding and mulching will take place. Construction will begin in the spring 2025 to finish up the final lift of pavement, seed the yards, and clean up from the project. The Water Treatment Plant is under construction and will continue through the winter and into the summer of 2025. 10/5/24 The Contractor has completed underground utility work on 1 st and 2 nd Streets East and will start the process of rebuilding the roadbed to gravel will begin the week of October 7th. Utility Construction with Start on Milkiway Avenue next week. 9/4/24 The contractors has reclaimed material on Farmdale, Meadowlane 1 st street east and 2 nd street east. They have removed some curb and gutter and sidewalk, and set up temporary water services in these areas.  They are scheduled begin with sewer, watermain and storm sewer in these areas in September. 6/25/24 The Contractor plans on starting the week of August 12, beginning with some tree removal and temporary water set up for residents. Pavement removal will start shortly after. The contractor is planning utility replacement at the end of August. Project Overview / Objectives Construction for Phase 4 the City of Lake Lillian’s Utility Improvements Project began August 2024. The locations of activities associated with Phase 4 of the project are shown on the map, and the work to be completed consisted of replacement of watermains, sanitary and storm sewers, and the repaving of affected roadways, which occurred in 2024. Watermain Construction Replace aging mains to reduce watermain breaks Sanitary Sewer Reconstruction Reduce risk of sewer backups Environmental Protection and compliance Correct slopes of pipe to proper 10 State Standards Storm Sewer Reconstruction Reduce localized flooding during big storms Street Reconstruction First layer of pavement installed in 2024 Final layer of pavement installed in spring/summer 2025 Areas of Construction in Lake Lillian Anticipated Schedule The following is a summary of the preliminary project schedule: August 2024 : Start of Construction September 2025 : Final Completion During construction, there will be some additional heavy truck and equipment traffic coming through town. It will be necessary to close streets partially or completely to vehicular traffic for your safety. Street parking may also be restricted at some times and in certain areas. Watermain replacement will require temporary watermains to provide water access throughout construction as watermains are taken offline for replacement. During key connections, you may experience brief water service interruptions and temporary changes in water quality as sediment in the pipe is disturbed by construction. Project Costs & Funding Project Funding for the Lake Lillian Infrastructure Improvements is 100% grants: $4.599Ml Resident Resources Click here for tips on turf restoration and how to care for your lawn after the construction project is complete. The City of Lake Lillian, Contractors, and Bollig Engineering ask that everyone stay clear of construction zones, obey construction signs, and be safe and cautious around construction equipment. If you have questions or concerns about the project, please contact Paul Dhoore, on-site Resident Project Representative (RPR),  Paul Jurek, Senior Engineer at 320-235-2555, or Dakota Tjaden, Project Engineer. Phase 4 - Project Progress Project started August 2024. Project Contacts Paul Dhoore Resident Project Representative Bollig Engineering pdhoore@bollig-engineering.com 320-235-2555 Paul Jurek, P.E. Her irrepressible determination to find and optimize strategies in pursuing any number of worthy issues is an inspiration.  Lil is dependable and conscientious, optimistic and cheerful; she would be great to have on your side in any struggle. ~ Cynthia Hoeh Stancioff Local Food Day Fiddlehead Festival Committee Member Passionate, Involved Within the first minute of conversation with Lillian Lake, it’s evident that you are speaking with a passionate and involved community member. Looking for the perfect venue for your next event? The Belleview Community Center offers a versatile space that's ideal for a wide range of gatherings. Whether you're planning a business meeting, a training session, or a personal celebration, our facility provides the perfect setting to make your event a success. With great amenities and a convenient location, it's the ideal choice for your event. Specifications Size: Floor Space - 45' X 35'; Total space of 1,750 Sq. ft. Capacity: 80 Facilities: Kitchenette area with full-sized refrigerator/freezer, microwave and sink. 2 Handicapped Accessible Bathrooms. Large event space with 16 tables and 78 chairs. NOTE: Tables are 8' rectangular. 75” wall-mounted, UHD TV; HDMI accessible; smart-tv allowing wireless connection through a personal hotspot. Splash Pad and Playground Park on the grounds (not included in the reservation). Organizational & Weekday Events The Belleview Community Center is perfect for meetings and training sessions. Organizations may be able to secure the space at no cost for free/low-cost community programs they offer. Please note that rentals for organizational and weekday events must take place between Monday and Thursday only and are secured in four (4) hour increments between 8:00am - 5:00pm. Reservation Process: For details on if you qualify for a zero rental cost and how to secure the space, please contact us at facilities@belleviewfl.org or call (352) 245-7021, ext. 2119. Review the Organizational/Weekday Rental Agreement BY CLICKING HERE. Personal & Weekend Events Ideal for: Birthday Parties Baby Showers and Bridal Showers Family Reunions and other Personal Events Personal/Weekend Events are secured as full-day rentals (10:00am - 10:00pm), Friday to Sunday. Reservation Process: Submit: Online reservation request Follow-Up: Receive an email within a week with a rental agreement for review and completion Deposit: Submit a $100 refundable deposit to hold the date Fees: For city-limit Belleview residents: $150 plus tax For non-residents: $300 plus tax NOTE: Having a Belleview street address DOES NOT mean you are a City of Belleview resident.  Our team will review all applications and will indicate the proper rental amount based on your address. Payment: Final rental payments are due no later than 15 days before the event date. Key Pickup: At Belleview City Hall during business hours (Mon - Thurs, 7:00 am - 6:00 pm) For full details on Personal/Weekend Event rentals, please review the rental agreement BY CLICKING HERE . Reserve the Belleview Community Center for your next meeting, training session, birthday party, shower, or family reunion. Enjoy our spacious facilities, equipped kitchen, and accessible amenities to ensure your event is a success. Submit your reservation request today and let us help you make your event memorable. For more information, contact us at facilities@belleviewfl.org or call (352) 245-7021, ext. 2119. All eyes on Lake Lillian area News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL All eyes on Lake Lillian area Nicki Gorny Staff writer Maybe once a week or so, Joshua Hathaway and his daughter, Kelly, can be found ambling around Belleview's Lake Lillian. It's a fairly short drive for the Summerfield family, and Hathaway said the playground equipment there is age-appropriate for 4-year-old Kelly. She also likes to walk the paths and help him fish, he added, and on a recent Friday afternoon tossed bread to the turtles and ducks gathered below the dock. But on a hot day like Friday, when afternoon temperatures crept toward 90 degrees, Hathaway said it would be nice to be able to stop nearby for a drink. That could be in the works, according to city representatives who outline a long-term plan to develop the neighborhood around Lake Lillian. By encouraging businesses to open in nearby homes, some of which are already fall under the mixed commercial-residential zoning that allows such uses, they hope to turn Lake Lillian into the heart of Belleview. “Belleview has a lot to offer,” said Commissioner Gary Ernst. *** Why it matters Belleview city and civic leaders have high hopes for the Lake Lillian area, which they hope to transform into the heart of town. How will they do this? We checked with government officials for the details on zoning, tax-funded projects and overall visioning. *** Bringing Lake Lillian in line with its potential will take “baby steps,” said Ernst, who has been in talks for two years already with Mariah Moody, executive director of the Belleview Economic Development Council. Mayor Christine Dobkowski said less concrete discussions about revitalizing the area predate her time on the City Commission, beginning in 2006, and that long-term revitalization goals at Lake Lillian largely prompted the city to organize a Community Redevelopment Area in 2013. The Community Redevelopment Area, or CRA, earmarks a portion of city and county property taxes collected in “Downtown Belleview” for neighborhood-specific improvements. The CRA is mapped out to cover approximately 225 acres of Belleview, including Lake Lillian and its southern neighborhood, as well as major thoroughfares such as Abshier Boulevard, County Road 484, Baseline Road, County Road 25 and Southeast Hames Road. The CRA fund today totals more than $26,000; no funds have yet been allocated and no projects have yet been outlined. A key part of plans for Lake Lillian's revitalization come today, according to Ernst and Moody, when construction crews from Oelrich Construction Inc. are set to break ground on the city's long-awaited splash park. To be located just a short walk from the lake, near the water tower and old public works building, the nearly $150,000 splash park is expected to draw residents and visitors to the area with its circular design, splash features such as geysers and jets, and an adjacent covered sitting area. Hathaway, for example, said he expects his daughter will love the new splash park. Kelly Durso, an Ocala mother who brought her son to Lake Lillian on Friday, said 2 1/2-year-old Pharaoh also will be a fan. If the neighborhood around Lake Lillian offered cafes, shops or offices, Moody said, splash park visitors like Hathaway or Durso might spend more of their day in Belleview. She and others envision for the neighborhood the sort of attorneys' or doctors' offices that dot Ocala's Historic District, where a home could serve as both a business and a residence. Some local businesses already operate within a few blocks of Lake Lillian, according to Sue Farnsworth, the city's development services director. These include Terry Harris Insurance, for example, or the Belleview Medical Center. Farnsworth said she has had preliminary meetings with at least two other business owners interested in converting part of a home into a spa or office. “We'd really like to see more,” she said. Opening a business is relatively simple for the homes south of Lake Lillian, which Farnsworth said are already zoned for commercial and residential use. Homes north of Lake Lillian are currently zoned residential; depending on how businesses progress on the south side of Lake Lillian, city representatives said, broadening zoning on that side of the lake as well is a long-term possibility. Lake Lillian Park and any businesses to its south also stand to benefit from CRA funds, although through what sort of projects remains to be seen. Dobkowski and Sandi McKamey, city clerk, said the CRA board (which doubles as the City Commission, although the two are separate entities) is waiting for a significant amount of money to build up in the fund before outlining any specific projects. While the city's CRA Plan, written in 2013, proposes multiple projects that address several areas of the CRA, Dobkowski said it is likely that early projects will address Lake Lillian. This could mean improvements to pathways or lighting, she said, or, generally, “things that would make it more desirable, so that business owners will be drawn to it.” The CRA is funded through property taxes, McKamey explained. Any home or business within the CRA pays to the city and county whatever taxes were owed in 2012; any taxes owed in excess of this level, based on inflation or rising property values, for example, go instead to the CRA fund. Lake Lillian Park has already benefited from efforts on the part of the city's public works department. Director Bruce Phillips said his department last year cleaned out the lake, in anticipation of the city's annual fishing derby, and added a dye that both gives the lake a green cast and controls weed and algae growth; it does not harm fish, birds or grass surrounding the lake. Phillips' department also continues to oversee the removal of the lake's resident Muscovy ducks, whose numbers he said are down to fewer than three dozen from an estimated 250 in September. While the ducks are a draw for young visitors such as Kelly and Pharaoh, Phillips said their presence near the splash park would be a health concern. While there is no timeline for revitalization efforts, city officials said they hope to see plans come together within five or 10 years. “It's coming together,” Ernst said. Search Local Events Our Parks Home Departments Parks & Recreation Local Events Local Events The following events are sponsored by the City of Belleview.  Stay up-to-date with events by following us on: Facebook: @cityofbelleview Instagram: @cityofbelleview Questions about an event?  Email us at events@belleviewfl.org today. Friday Foodie Fest Held the third Friday of every month, January - September, at Lake Lillian, this monthly event features lots of family fun! Centered around food trucks, music, free activities for children, and shop with local businesses and craft vendors while enjoying yummy food. Come for the food and stay for the fun! NOTE: ALL vendor (Food/Non-Food) are FILLED for the remaining Friday Foodie Fest events of 2025. NOTE : Registration for NON-FOOD TRUCK VENDORS for the 2026 season is now open.  This form can be used to register if you are either (a) a cottage industry vendor, (b) a non-food vendor or (c) a nonprofit organization.  Food Trucks will be secured through a different form at a later date. Once received, our office will process and issue invoices for the selected dates. Click HERE to complete a NON-FOOD TRUCK VENDOR APPLICATION for the 2026 Friday Foodie Fest season. For information on general vendor requirements/costs, please email rvass@belleviewfl.org . ———————————————————————————————————————— Crafting Connection: building community through creativity program series Cost: $0 per person - NOW FREE! Join us on Wednesday, September 17, 2025 from 6pm - 8pm at the Belleview Community Center.  Participants are encouraged to bring their own crafting project and receive insights from our experts. PLUS, we'll have a special surprise craft project perfect for kids and adults. Children are welcome - coloring books and Legos are provided. Click HERE to register for the event. ———————————————————————————————————————— Freedom Walk The Freedom Walk is held each year on 9/11 in remembrance of the victims of 9/11/2001. The event includes a short ceremony with local first responders at the Belleview Community Center and is followed by a solemn walk.  All are welcome to join the walk and the ceremony. The 2025 Freedom Walk will take place at the Belleview Community Center (5615 SE 110th Place) starting at 6:00pm on September 11, 2025. ———————————————————————————————————————— Trunk or Treat Held in October on the Saturday before Halloween, this is a free family fun event that provides safe trick-or-treating including games, hayrides, and more! Trunk-or-Treat, powered by Gary Yeoman's Ford, is a fun way to promote your business/organization while being involved with the community. The 2025 Trunk or Treat will be held on Saturday, October 25, 2025 from 4:00pm - 7:00pm by Lake Lillian. Click HERE to register as a vehicle/trunk. Space is limited. ———————————————————————————————————————— Light Up Lake Lillian Held the first Saturday in December, citizens from all over South Marion County come to participate in Lake Lillian’s first lighting for the holiday season. Attendees can enjoy a visit from Santa as well as free arts and crafts and children's activities. Vendors offer a wide variety of food and merchandise. 2025 Light Up Lake Lillian will be held on Saturday, December 6, 2025 from 2:00 pm - 7:00 pm. Click HERE to register as a Vendor for Light Up Lake Lillian. Nonfood Truck and Cottage Industry Vendors ONLY. ———————————————————————————————————————— PAW Chili Challenge & HUBCAT Car Show The 2026 PAW Chili Challenge & HUBCAT Car Show, presented by Sheltering Hands Inc., will take place on January 24, 2026, from 12 PM to 4 PM at Lake Lillian in Belleview. Attendees can enjoy a vendor marketplace, food trucks, inflatables, games, and music, with a chili cook-off featuring CASI and Open competitions. Proceeds benefit the United Way of Marion County and Sheltering Hands. Click HERE to register as a non-food vendor, commercial business, nonprofit or cottage industry vendor. ———————————————————————————————————————— Annual Fishing Derby Fishing is Fun, and whether your kids are beginners or pros, they will have a great time at our annual fishing derby. Lake Lillian is stocked yearly to prepare for this event by the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission with catfish and bass. Open to children ages 15 and under and held annually at Lake Lillian in April or May, this free event offers a morning of fishing with bait provided and prizes in two categories for biggest fish and most fish caught. We wrap the derby up with a free community cookout hosted by our Belleview Police Department. Registration for the 2026 Youth Fishing Derby will open in the spring. Come back for more info. ———————————————————————————————————————— Founder's Day Our Annual Founder's Day will take place Saturday, May 2, 2026 between 10:00am - 3:00pm at Lake Lillian. Event attendees can enjoy a variety of craft, business, and food vendors! Free children's activities include games, crafts, and inflatables as well as activities and booths focusing on our city's history! Vendor Registration will open in Spring 2026. ———————————————————————————————————— Gregg Smith Automotive Car Show at Founder's Day Rev up your engines and register your ride for the Gregg Smith Automotive Car Show at Belleview Founder’s Day on Saturday, May 2, 2026, from 10 AM to 3 PM . Whether you own a sleek modern car, a timeless classic, a rugged Jeep, or a powerful truck, there’s a category for you. Pre-register online for just $10 or sign up at the event for $15. All proceeds benefit the United Way of Marion County, so you can show off your vehicle while supporting a great cause. Trophies, raffles, 50/50, music, food trucks and more. Online Registration for vehicles will open in Spring 2026. ———————————————————————————————————————— NON-CITY EVENTS Christmas Parade Held the first Sunday in December, citizens from all over South Marion County come to enjoy the annual Belleview Christmas Parade to kick off the holiday season. The parade is organized and coordinated by Friends of the Christmas Parade, LLC. A man was found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound on a public bench near the lake. According to reports, a woman and her mother discovered the body during an everyday walk and immediately alerted authorities. Belleview police responded quickly, covering the scene and securing the area with caution tape. Nearby businesses heard the sound of the gunshot but didn't see anything amiss. What makes this incident particularly troubling is its proximity to a playground, where children were actively playing while the scene was being processed. Identification was made, but they have not yet released the man’s name as the investigation remains ongoing and his family needs to be notified first. Search Business Tax Brochure Change of Tenancy Application Business Resource List New Business Information Guide Forms and Applications Home Business Information Pay Your Business Taxes Online Home Departments Development Services Business Information & Resources Business Information & Resources Starting a new business is exciting.  Whether you are starting a small home business or expanding into a larger location, the resources in this section will help you through the process. Start with the Small Business Administration for general guidance on financial, legal, and logistical matters. Additional information on starting a small business may be found by visiting the Division of Library and Information Services page. Florida SBDC Network provides a series of live and virtual training events, including how to start a business. Before purchasing property or signing a lease, contact Belleview Planning and Zoning to confirm zoning and any local regulations that may apply to your business. City applications and information for opening or moving different types of businesses are provided below. Please contact staff to help you find the appropriate form and discuss the approval process. Located Inside the City Limits A new business that moves in to the city must go through the Change of Tenancy permit process. The City Building Official and Marion County Fire Prevention will perform inspections on the unit to ensure it meets Florida Building Code and Fire Prevention Code and is safe for your business. The following steps will help you through the process of opening your business. The fee is based on the type of business and the square footage or seating capacity of the unit. Download the Change of Tenancy Application (PDF) . For a list of Local Business Tax fees: Click Here For additional applications please visit our Forms & Applications Page Mobile Business New mobile businesses, such as food trucks, mobile detailing, ice cream trucks and other roadside sales are required to obtain a local business tax receipt to operate inside the city limits. Documentation such as food handling licenses, fictitious name registration, etc., that are required by the state, must be submitted with the application. The fee is $52.05. Download the Business Tax with No Physical Location Application (PDF) . Home Business Do you work from home? Home businesses must also apply for a local business tax receipt and meet the requirements for a home business. The cost $11.55 for the Home Business Tax Receipt. Download the Home Business Tax Application (PDF) . Existing Business Annual Fire Inspection Permit To apply for an annual fire inspection, please complete and submit this application to the Building Department.  The fee is $60.  Examples of annual inspections include daycares, nursing homes, private schools, etc.  An annual fire inspection permit may also be requested for any business that wishes to have an inspection as required by insurance or for licensing purposes. Download the Annual Fire Inspection Application (PDF) Seasonal Business - Tent Sales Seasonal businesses are tent sales for fireworks and Christmas tree sales. The permit fee is $204.00 and $63.60 (annually) for the Business Tax Receipt. Download the Seasonal Sale Business Tax Application (PDF) . Seasonal Sales - Christmas Parade-Special Events Seasonal Sales are vendors selling food/drinks/toys and other items at events such as the Belleview Christmas Parade. The business tax receipt is $63.60 and is limited to the day of the event. Digital pictures of each employee are required and badges will be assigned for the day of the event. Download the Seasonal Sales/Christmas Parade Business Tax Application (PDF) . Commercial and Group Use of City Parks Commercial and group users of City Parks are persons or entities that offer instruction, education, care, supervision or services and charge a fee for such activity or service. This includes child care groups, schools and camps. All commercial and group users of city parks must have a valid permit prior to use of setting up equipment. This application also applies to mobile food vendors selling products or setting up equipment on City property. Download the Commercial and Group Use Application (PDF). Completed applications and fees are to be submitted to the Events & Promotions Manager. FAQs What is a business tax? How do I open a business in the City of Belleview? Can I use my home as my office space for my business? He was an Emmy Award winning producer early in his career. Larry has managed stations all over the country with his most recent stops in Houston, TX and Indianapolis, IN. Larry is a 1975 graduate of Lake Land College and a 1977 graduate of Indiana State University. Larry and his wife Brenda (also an LLC grad) have one daughter, Hillary who lives in Santa Barbara, CA. Larry and Brenda reside in La Quinta, California. They are proud to be Lake Land grads and are always quick to give LLC much of the credit for any successes they have had. In 2011, they established the Blackerby Endowment for LLC broadcasting students. Tom White Vice President Charleston, IL Tom White is the Chief Technology Officer at Consolidated Communications and is responsible for the company’s network design and development, engineering, company facilities, corporate purchasing, and supply chain, in addition to the administration of the company’s capital investments. He joined the company in 1992 as a Supervisor in the company’s former Operator Services division and has held multiple management and leadership positions during his career with the company including field operations, network operations, OSP and network engineering. White is active in his local community and currently serves on the Lake Land Foundation and has served on the Coles Together Board, Charleston Excellence in Foundation Board and the CCAR Industries Board. He earned in bachelor’s degree in business administration and management from Virginia Commonwealth University and lives in Charleston with his wife and three children. Amanda Martin Secretary Paris, IL Rich Hartke Immediate Past President Teutopolis, IL Richard Hartke, a Lake Land alumni, is a Financial Professional with The Prudential Insurance Company of America. He has been in the financial services industry for 20+ years serving both Effingham and Champaign, Illinois communities. He has earned MDRT Life Member designation, Life Founders Gold Award and Masters Council recognitions. Passionate for technology within education, Rich served on the Teutopolis committee, which raised funds to provide every student within Teutopolis schools a Chromebook. Rich and his wife, Angie, are life-long residents of Teutopolis, IL where they have raised their three children. He is also the President of Teutopolis Community For Progress, a board dedicated to the economic development and improvement of its community. Madge Shoot Treasurer, Ex-Officio Mattoon, IL Ms. Shoot is the Comptroller for Lake Land College. Ms. Shoot serves as the treasurer of the Lake Land College Alumni Association. Ms. Shoot also teaches adjunct business classes for Lake Land College. She was previously employed as an Assistant Controller for a local manufacturing firm. She received a bachelor’s degree in accounting from Eastern Illinois University and a Master’s in Business Administration and is also an alumni of Lake Land College. Angela Dyer Paris, IL Angela Dyer, a 1994 Lake Land graduate, is employed by First Neighbor Bank in Paris, IL. She has worked in community banking, as a Paris native, for 28 years. Currently serving her neighbors as a Branch Manager and Vice President for the company. Angela stays connected in Edgar County by engaging in community events and various organizations. As a United Way board member, past director for the Paris Area Chamber of Commerce, and current Ambassador for the Paris Chamber, she stays involved and active in the community. Angela resides in Paris with her husband, a local farmer for more than 30 years, also from Paris. Together, they have 5 children; 2 living at home, 3 living and working in the area, and 2 grandchildren. For fun, she and her spouse like to travel by motorcycle to see the beautiful and inspiring landscapes of America. Dr. Jonathan “Josh” Bullock President of Lake Land College, Ex-Officio Mattoon, IL Dr. Bullock has served as the chief executive officer of the college since July 1, 2013, responsible to the Lake Land College Board of Trustees.  Prior to joining Lake Land College Dr. Bullock served as the Vice President for Strategic Advancement at Moraine Park Technical College in Fond du Lac, WI. Under Dr. Bullock’s leadership, Lake Land College has implemented a comprehensive strategic planning process, initiated Guided Pathways and co-requisite remediation frameworks for student success, integrated a data analytics platform to facilitate data-driven decision making, enriched the Lake Land brand, developed unique training models to assist local businesses in sustaining a skilled workforce, strengthened high school dual credit opportunities, began the Presidential Scholarship program to provide educational opportunities for talented high school graduates, and undertaken efforts to modernize campus infrastructure and technology. Dr. Bullock is passionate about ensuring educational opportunities are accessible to all Illinois residents, including those under incarceration. He is proud of Lake Land’s partnership with the Illinois Department of Corrections in serving incarcerated students through full-time college degree programs at 25 Illinois adult and juvenile correctional facilities throughout Illinois, providing opportunity and reducing recidivism for the most vulnerable students. He is a long-standing Rotarian and is actively engaged in communities throughout east central Illinois, serving as a board member for numerous organizations including Coles Together, The Effingham Regional Growth Alliance, the Christian County Economic Development Corporation, the East Central Illinois Development Corporation and the Sarah Bush Lincoln Health System. Appointed by Governor J.B. Pritzker as a Commissioner with the Illinois Student Assistance Commission, Dr. Bullock is actively engaged in advocating for the success of students across Illinois. He currently serves as Chair of the Illinois Council of Community College Presidents and has nearly 30 years of experience in higher education as a teacher and administrator, in addition to a successful career in the private sector. He earned a Doctor of Philosophy from Marian University, a Master of Business Administration from the University of Wisconsin – Oshkosh and a Bachelor of Business Administration from the University of Wisconsin – Madison. Christi Donsbach Executive Director for College Advancement/Foundation CEO, Ex-Officio Teutopolis, IL Christi Donsbach serves at the Executive Director for College Advancement at Lake Land College. In her role, Christi leads the Foundation and alumni areas of the college and serves as the chief executive officer of the Lake Land College Foundation. With a primary focus on philanthropy, alumni engagement and building of community partnerships, she works closely with key stakeholders both within the college and throughout the college district, and serves as a catalyst for donor and volunteer involvement for the Foundation through a variety of operational activities. Christi joined the college in October of 2019 with more than 14 years of experience in fostering a culture of philanthropy in a college setting. Ms. Donsbach came to Lake Land College from Eastern Illinois University (EIU), where she served as the director of development and was responsible for the leadership and management of alumni and friends to an assigned fundraising portfolio, as well as planned giving. She also taught a university foundation introductory course and presented at several regional educational seminars. Prior to joining EIU, Christi served as the director of donor & alumni relations at Midland Institute for Entrepreneurship in Effingham, director of development & alumni relations at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville and director of development at Pony Bird Inc. in Mapaville, Missouri. Christi holds memberships in the Association of Fundraising Professionals (AFP) and Council for Advancement and Support of Education (CASE) professionally and in several community organizations. She recently served on the membership committee for AFP and served as co-chair for the CASE District V conference. She is a member of the Effingham Chamber of Commerce, a past member of the Effingham PEO, a member of the St. Aloysius Church has served as a mentor in Effingham County CEO. She was also recognized as one of Effingham Illinois’ Top Community Leaders Under 40 in 2015. Christi has a bachelor’s degree in marketing from Southern Illinois University Carbondale and a master’s degree in business administration from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville. She lives in Teutopolis with her husband, Jake, and their four children. Kathleen Anderson Hindsboro, IL Kathleen is a proud 1976 graduate of Lake Land College.  She is retired after a 30 year career in banking in Oakland and Charleston.  Kathleen and her husband, Mike (who also attended Lake Land College) have lived and farmed near Hindsboro for 44 years.  They have two children, Brian and Lucy, and six grandchildren.  Besides the LLC Foundation Board, Kathleen currently serves on the Board for St. Hedwig Haus of Hospitality in Charleston, the Oakland Area Chamber of Commerce and the Peace Meal Project Advisory Council.  She enjoys volunteering at Coles County Habitat for Humanity and Coalition for People in Need. Layna Bond Highland, IL A 2016 Lake Land graduate, Layna Bond, is the owner of Bond and Associates LLC with American Family Insurance. She grew up on a small swine and cattle operation in Galatia, IL, where she exhibited livestock at various levels. During her time at Lake Land, Layna was a Student Ambassador and member of the Livestock Judging Team. After graduating in 2016, she transferred to Oklahoma State University, where she obtained her bachelor’s in animal science and was a member of the 2017 National Champion Livestock Judging Team. Following her time at OSU, she attended Kansas State University, where she studied for her master’s in beef cattle breeding and genetics. In July (2024) , Layna will have run her own insurance business for two years. Choosing this career was easy for her as it has allowed her to give back to the livestock industry while still being actively involved in the community. Her background and experience make farm and life insurance her most popular policies; however, she can sell multiple other types of policies including business owners, home, auto, umbrella, etc. Bond and Associates LLC currently has two offices, one in Effingham, IL, and the other in Highland, IL. She attributes Lake Land College for her current success. Layna is a member of the Effingham Chamber of Commerce, Highland Chamber of Commerce, Effingham RISE BNI, and sits on the board for the Madison County Fair. She also founded the Cheers for Charity for FISH in Effingham. Remaining engaged in the community holds significant importance for her, as she strives to foster relationships with all her customers, ensuring their proper protection. Layna currently resides in Highland, IL and looks forward to giving back to a community who formed her into who she is today. Kellie Eastham Paris, IL Kellie Eastham currently serves as Partner-Vice President of Personal Lines at Dimond Bros. Insurance. Kellie enjoys her role as a servant leader to her teams in IL, WI and IN. Prior to her time in insurance, she spent her career in the banking industry where she served the banking community for 15+ years. Kellie and her husband Cory reside in Paris, IL with their two children, Carter and Hadlee.  Kellie has served as past Paris Chamber of Commerce President, as well as President of the Paris Business Women’s Club. You can find Kellie leading worship at her home church, or cheering on her kids at local softball, basketball, football, or baseball games. Austin Frank Mattoon, IL Austin Frank, Laker Nation class of 2006, serves as Senior Vice President & Director of Investor Relations for First Mid Bank & Trust in Mattoon.  Austin is a member of the Mattoon Chamber of Commerce, Mattoon Emerging Leaders and supports many local charities.  Austin previously served as student loan advisor and adjunct business instructor at Lake Land College.  Austin also served on the Lake Land College Alumni Association Board of Directors, served as President of the Alumni Association and was the 2020 recipient of the Alumni Association’s Golden Apple award.  Austin received his MBA and Bachelor of Science degree in Finance from Eastern Illinois University and an Associate of Science degree in Business Administration from Lake Land College where he was a member of the men’s tennis team. Tyler Micenheimer Effingham, IL Gary Philippi Casey, IL Gary grew up on a small farm in Cumberland County and upon his retirement in 2017 he and his wife, Jeanie (also from Casey), returned home. Gary is a 1970 graduate of Lake Land College. He obtained his B.A. and his M.A. in education administration from Eastern Illinois University. He began his is career in education in the Arcola C.U.S.D. He left education in 1977 and returned to education at Arcola after 22 years in private business in Windsor, where he was owner/operator of an insurance agency. He remained in Arcola as teacher/principal for 10 years.  In 2009 he became the director of the Eastern Illinois Education for Employment System. Gary was active throughout the LLC area. He served on the Shelby County Board, Shelby County Mental Health Board, Sarah Bush Lincoln Health Care System Board and many other community associations. Statewide he served on the Illinois Principal Association Board as well as the Illinois Association of Career and Technical Association Board. Upon his retirement he has remained active in number of community activities and church. Gary has seen the great influence of Lake Land College on the area community over the years and looks forward to contributing to that influence. Terry McConnell Mattoon, IL Mr. McConnell retired in 2009 from RR Donnelley. At the time of his retirement, he was a customer account manager serving magazine and catalog publishers. He has been associated with Lake Land College either as a student or adjunct faculty member since 1972. He also served on the Lake Land College Alumni Association Board of Directors for many years. He has taught business classes in Charleston, Effingham and the Mattoon campus. Mr. McConnell received an Associate in Science and Associate in Applied Science degrees from Lake Land College and his bachelor of science in business education from Eastern Illinois University. He and his wife Melody have one daughter, Nicole, and reside in Mattoon. Amy Shafer Mattoon, IL Kurt Rankin Charleston, IL Rudy Huber Sullivan, IL Rudy Huber, Sullivan, a 1976 Lake Land College graduate, began farming the same year in Douglas County. He began auctioneering with his father in 1981, joining the Huber Auction Team. In 2000, he became a licensed independent insurance agent with CF & H Insurance, located in Sullivan, Windsor and Monticello, where his wife, Linda is president. Huber is also a Republican Precinct Committeeman and a member of the Sullivan Rotary and Sullivan Country Club. He is a former board member of these organizations, as well. Bob Payton Wichita Falls, TX Bob Payton is a self-employed business and leadership consultant based in Wichita Falls, Texas.  He works with mid-sized organizations in five states on organizational development, project management, mergers and acquisitions and business development efforts. Bob’s early career was in radio broadcasting, starting during high school in Salem, IL.  His choice for college was the Radio/TV program at Lake Land College, where he graduated with an Associates in Applied Sciences degree in 1978.  He continued his studies at Eastern Illinois University and then continued his radio career for 25 years. Bob deeply believes in servant leadership and giving back, especially through faith-based and educational institutions.  He has been involved in numerous community organizations throughout his career, most notably serving 18 years on the Wichita Falls Independent School District board of trustees. Bob’s wife Lori is from Newton, IL.  They have one son who lives and works in the Dallas, TX area. Tom Wright Board of Trustees Liaison Dieterich, IL Wright, Laker Nation Class of 1973, brings a multitude of experience serving on boards and leading a business to the trustee position. He has served as the president of Wright’s Furniture in Dieterich for the past 30 years and is a member of the Cross at the Crossroads Board, the Dieterich Bank Board, the Alliance Board and the Dieterich Community Development Corporation. He has served on the Lake Land College Foundation Board of Directors for twelve years, including as president from 2010-2012, and he served on the St. Anthony Hospital Board of Directors for nine years and the Effingham County 911 Board for four years. Wright received the Lake Land College Alumnus Achievement Award in 2009, the Lake Land College Foundation Crystal Swan Award in 2015 and was inducted into the inaugural class of the Distinguished Alumni Society in 2007. In 2018, Wright was named as one of Lake Land’s “Top 50 Most Influential People.” Debra Sandercock Charleston, IL Debra joined the U. S. Air Force after graduating from Duke University with degrees in nursing and history. Later, she completed her Master of Science in Nursing at the University of Cincinnati. After 15 years in the U. S. Air Force and attaining the rank of Major, Debra transitioned to civilian employment. As a nurse, Debra has worked in several different roles over the years: staff nurse, administrator, and pediatric nurse practitioner Growing up in a military family and then being in the service herself, she moved thirty-three times before settling in Illinois with her husband and four daughters. After this final move, Debra chose not to work outside the home any further and devoted herself to philanthropy and her family. She has volunteered her time over a variety of community organizations; including Daughters of the American Revolution, PEO, church youth groups, local hospital committees, Women Connected Giving Circle and now Lake Land College Foundation Board of Directors. Meg Yargus Steward Marshall, IL Meg Yargus Steward is a native to Marshall, IL and recently joined her family’s business, Yargus Enterprises, making up Hannig Construction, Central State Construction, B&S Plumbing, Heating & Cooling, and Crown Electric.  Steward worked in the fertilizer industry for over a decade selling material handling equipment to key accounts. Her ease with customers, passion for customer service and ability to adapt easily will make her a good fit to grow the team and brands in the surrounding area. She is the Marketing Manager and earned her bachelor’s degree in Marketing from Butler University in 2006. Steward recently joined the Wabash Valley Crew Board and has been a supporter of Lake Land College for years. She sat on the Board of Trustees in 2017-2018 and rejoined for the Foundation Board in 2019. She also sits on the Illinois Fertilizer and Chemicals Association and PAC Boards based in Springfield, IL. Linda VonBehren Martinsville, IL Linda grew up on a farm near Moonshine and has a love for farming and agriculture. She raises sheep with her family. She earned a Bachelor and Masters in Education from Eastern Illinois University. Linda retired from Lake Land College as the Associate Vice President for Workforce and was recognized as one of the Top 50 Most Influential People in Lake Land’s 50-year history. She served on the Martinsville School Board for over 26 years. She is currently involved with ECCEL Committee serving Edgar and Clark County students and WORC Board of Directors. Linda is an Elder at the Willow Creek Church. She is a life long resident of the Moonshine area. Whether you're looking for a peaceful retreat or an active day outdoors, Lake Lillian provides the perfect backdrop. Lake Lillian is more than just a park; it is a vibrant community hub. The lake hosts many popular city events throughout the year, including Founder's Day, Trunk or Treat, Friday Foodie Fests, and Light Up Lake Lillian. These events bring the community together and offer fun and entertainment for all ages. Belleview residents can take advantage of reserving the large pavilion at no charge. Belleview demolishes 'dilapidated' house in Lake Lillian Park News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals COUNTY Belleview demolishes 'dilapidated' house in Lake Lillian Park 'It's right dead in the middle of our park' Katie Pohlman katie.pohlman@starbanner.com BELLEVIEW — Demolition of a recently purchased city of Belleview property began Wednesday to make way for a continuous Lake Lillian Park. Belleview City Commission members approved the purchase and demolition of the home on May 16 with a 3-1 vote. A little more than $91,000 was set aside for the entire project. The property itself was purchased for the appraised price of $83,000. The property, dubbed the "Denker House" by city officials, sits just west of Lake Lillian. "It's right dead in the middle of our park," Public Works Director Bruce Phillips told the commission during its May 2 meeting. The owner originally asked $114,900 for the property, Phillips said, but later agreed to the appraised price. By Thursday morning, the house had already been reduced to a pile of debris. And a construction crew was moving the debris into a dumpster with the help of a claw excavator. The former two-story wood-framed house had some problem residents, Mayor Christine Dobkowski said. During one discussion, she called the home "dilapidated and abandoned." Commissioner Gary Ernst said he had seen syringes and needles outside the house multiple times. "It doesn't fit into our master plan," he said. The Lake Lillian Park Master Plan is part of Belleview's community redevelopment plan. It includes several improvements, such as replacing footpaths with recreation trails, replacing the electrical system and renovating the old public works department building into a new community center. In February, commissioners approved the hiring of Kimley-Horn and Associates, Inc. to construct a plan for the park. Plans for the community center were presented to the commission in May. While many commissioners were not adamant proponents of purchasing the Denker house, the only one who voted against it was Commissioner Michael Goldman. "We are removing a taxable piece of property from the tax rolls," he argued May 16. "We are taking that burden and placing it on the shoulders of everyone else that pays taxes on their property. "Government," he added, "shouldn't be in the business of purchasing property." Commissioner Robert "Bo" Smith agreed with Goldman during the many discussions the commission had about the property, but stated he thought it would be well worth it to purchase and demolish the home. Dobkowski said she had reservations about the plans when first approached by Phillips but also thought it would be worth it. She said the green space of the property, instead of problems some residents had posed, would be better for the park and community. "This is for the benefit of the parks, community," Ernst echoed. "It's for the benefit of the city of Belleview." Commissioner Ronald Livsey was not at the meeting when the Denker property purchase was voted on. No public comments by citizens were made at any of the meetings involving discussions of the Denker house. Phillips said after the house is completely removed, city staff will work on cleaning up the property. All the trees will remain, but the undergrowth will be cleaned. The city will next focus on demolishing the old outbuildings in Lake Lillian Park and cleaning up the area around them, Phillips said.
